FRIDAY IS PATRIOT DAY
September 11 marks a tragic day in U.S. history. Our nation’s flag will be flown at half-staff from sunrise to sunset at every school and the District Office. We will also continue the ASD tradition of raising the Freedom Flag to honor the 1,977 people who lost their lives and the 6,000 more who injured at the World Trade Center in New York City, the Pentagon in Washington, D.C. and on U.S. Air Flight 93 in Shanksville, PA. We ask everyone to join us in observing a moment of silence in honor of those who made the ultimate sacrifice for freedom that day. Please note: Due to COVID-19, the Air Force JROTC’s public ceremony at Middletown High was cancelled. Look for it to return next year.
For more about the Freedom Flag, an emblem of remembrance and education, visit our website https://www.apposchooldistrict.com/apps/news/show_news.jsp?REC_ID=663051&id=0.

post_text: Families who qualify for reduced price school meals, but struggle to pay for them no longer have to worry! - The Appoquinimink School District is pleased to announce that beginning this September, the School Nutrition Services Department will absorb the cost (40 cents per lunch, 30 cents per breakfast) of providing reduced-price meals to students who are eligible for the benefit. Explains School Nutrition Supervisor Janice Vander-Decker, “We know that many families are struggling with financial uncertainty. For years, the National School Nutrition Association has advocated on Capitol Hill for the elimination of the reduced-price category. But some challenges are better solved locally. This summer, we found that, with careful long-range planning, Appoquinimink’s School Nutrition Services Department could absorb the cost without requiring more support from the District or its taxpayers. It’s the right thing to do, and we’re moving forward quickly to make it a reality.” Story continues... http://edne.tw/n652838

post_text: MON., FEB 17: SCHOOLS & OFFICES ARE CLOSED - President's Day is the popular name for a federal holiday officially called Washington's Birthday. The day, in practice, is often used to honor and remember ALL past Presidents of our nation, and in particular George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson. President's Day was the first federal holiday ever created. It was celebrated on February 22 (Washington's actual date of birth) well into the 20th Century when Congress passed the Monday Holiday Law to "provide uniform annual observances of certain legal public holidays on Mondays." DID YOU KNOW? The reading of George Washington's Farewell Address is an annual event in the Senate. The Purple Heart military badge (which carries an image of Washington) for soldiers injured in the course of duty is awarded on President's Day. Read more in an article entitled, By George, IT IS Washington's Birthday! at https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2004/winter/gw-birthday-1.html. http://edne.tw/n613385

A simple reminder about what you can do to prevent its spread, and an update on the coronavirus. - Although the spread of the coronavirus has captured the world’s attention, public health officials say that, for now at least, Delawareans should be more concerned about catching the flu. Health experts at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention say it's too early to know when the flu season will peak or how severe it will be. But we do know that, by January 18, a total of 2,415 flu cases had been confirmed in Delaware, which is about 1,000 more cases that than this time last year.* That's why school nurses, who are health care experts, are reaching out to make sure students and adults practice everyday prevention, recognize early flu symptoms, and, if they do become sick, take the steps needed to prevent its spread. Loss Elementary School Third Grade Teacher Danielle Rash are part of an elite group of 215 STEM educators who, in October 2019, were named Presidential Award winners for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching (PAEMST). post_text: The MOT area is in the midst of a population boom. We're certainly aware of it in our schools. In the last five years, Appoquinimink's student enrollment has swelled by 19 percent (1,860 students). We're currently growing by 435 students – the size of a Townsend Elementary School – each year. More children mean we need more teachers; more support staff; more security; more textbooks; more technology; more furniture; more transportation; and, of course, more room to learn! Click on our video link to hear a short interview with Superintendent Matt Burrows, Board President Richard Forsten and Referendum Co-Chair Cyndi Clay.

post_text: Highlights from Middletown High's appearance at the Atlantic Coast Championships - The Cavalier Marching Band ended a hard-fought competitive season placing 4th overall at the Tournament of Band's Atlantic Coast Championship in Hershey, PA over the weekend. The group narrowly missed 2nd place - just 0.3 separated them from two other groups who tied for 2nd place in Group 3-Open Class; and they were only 0.9 of a point from 1st! The Cavs brought home the award for "Best Visual Design" – a first for our program at this event – and Senior Paige Bell was awarded a $1,000 scholarship from Tournament of Bands. On November 2, Appo High's Band, the Jags, will take the field to compete in the Group 4 Open Class at Hershey. Stay tuned for the results! http://edne.tw/n596016
